repnme.cdata!:
Eritrea - Health Project, and HIV/AIDS,
            Malaria, STD and Tuberculosis Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Project for
            Eritrea are as follows: outcome was moderately
            unsatisfactory; risk to the development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory; and
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory.
            Ratings for the HIV/AIDS, Malaria, STD and Tuberculosis
            Control Project for Eritrea are as follows: outcome was
            moderately satisfactory; risk to the development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            projects included: in post-conflict settings engagement is a
            means to an end and needs to be accompanied by a sustained
            policy dialogue to ensure that development gains are
            realized in the medium term. In the area of HIV/AIDS a
            demand-driven model of community sub-projects is more
            appropriate for service delivery interventions that are
            responsive to local community needs (such as home-based
            care, support to orphans and vulnerable children) than for
            preventive interventions targeting stigmatized risk groups
            or stigmatized behavior. Community activities that are
            strategically planned and coordinated with the local health
            authorities can provide an important complement to health
            facility-based disease control efforts. Disease control
            projects can be complementary to and need not undermine
            cross-cutting health system functions. Multi-sector
            projects, such as HIV/AIDS projects, achieve better results
            if the sectors involved are strategically chosen according
            to their comparative advantage in disease prevention and control.

10823371.trustfund:
TF021422-ERITREA HEALTH,TF029416-PHRD-BASIC EDUCATION/HEALTH PROJECT,TF033823-ERITREA - HEALTH,TF038871-ERITREA - SUPERVISIONOF
            HIV/AIDS/MALARIA/STD/TB CONTROL PROJECT,TFM21422-ERITREA HEALTH,TFS21422-ERITREA HEALTH,TF028941-HIV/AIDS/MALARIA/SEXUALLY
            TRANSMITTED DISEASES/TUBERCULOSIS CONTROBL PR,TF030371-DANISH CTF FY03 - SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA,TF039359-ERITREA - HEALTH RESTRUCTURING PROJECT,TF040120-ERITREA: HIV/AIDS

abstracts.cdata!:
In spite of substantial institutional
            development impacts, and likely sustainability, ratings
            convey an unsatisfactory project outcome. Lessons are
            addressed as follows. During project preparation, it is
            suggested to avoid ambitious development objectives, and
            inappropriate key performance indicators, particularly, in
            post-conflict, and ongoing border dispute situations, rather
            a realistic and modest approach should be followed, through
            a Project design, built on solid economic and sector work
            (ESW). This project suffered from a lack of analytical work
            in the country. Thus, some health sector analyses,
            particularly on the status of the country's primary and
            secondary health care, would have helped the project
            preparation significantly. During project implementation,
            Project activities succeeded due to key factors, namely, a
            government highly committed to the project, strong
            leadership in the Ministry of Health (MOH), a capable and
            motivated implementing agency, and, the Bank's
            commitment to country ownership and willingness to help
            during supervision. However, it was a missed opportunity
            that during the Project's Mid-Term Review (MTR), the
            project design problems were not corrected. Lessons
            regarding Hospital construction indicate that once tender
            documents for civil works have been finalized, and contracts
            agreed, changes should only be made if absolutely necessary,
            by duly and carefully scrutinizing tender documents.

5084128.trustfund:
TF034744-AFRICA REGION - ERITREA 1ST
            HEALTH PROJECT, ETHIOPIA - INVESTMENT,TF033823-ERITREA - HEALTH,TF029416-PHRD-BASIC EDUCATION/HEALTH PROJECT,TF030561-CANADA GENERAL CTF - FY04 -
            AFRICA (HEALTH),TF033820-ERITREA - HEALTH,TF021422-ERITREA HEALTH,TF038871-ERITREA - SUPERVISIONOF
            HIV/AIDS/MALARIA/STD/TB CONTROL PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Progress in achieving the development
            objective of the Health Project in Eritrea will be evaluated
            based on reductions in 1) infant and under-five mortality
            rates, maternal mortality ratios, and total fertility rates;
            2) prevalence rates of malnutrition in women and in
            under-five children, tuberculosis, malaria, diarrhea, acute
            respiratory infections (ARI), sexually transmitted diseases
            (STDs) and Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS); and
            prevalence of female genital mutilation practices. The
            project's components strengthen health care services by
            1) increasing access by building, equipping, and staffing
            referral hospitals; and by providing equipment, furniture,
            essential drugs and vaccines, training providers, improving
            management, and developing national blood bank services; and
            2) building capacity, improving sectoral planning and
            management, and the financial sustainability of health
            programs through training, study tours, pilot interventions,
            and testing of local level mechanisms to raise, retain, and
            use additional revenues for health services; and improve
            project management and implementation.
